t: Job 10
Job: I Would Plead with God
“My*pn soul loathes my life; I*ld will give free course to my complaint, I*ld will speak in the bitterness of my soul.
I*ld will say to God, ‘Do not condemn me; Show*ld me why You contend with me.
Does*ild it*i seem good to You that You should oppress, That*ld You should despise the work of Your hands, And*ld smile on the counsel of the wicked?
Do*ld You have eyes of flesh? Or*ld do You see as man sees?
Are*ild Your days like the days of a mortal man? Are*ild Your years like the days of a mighty man,
That*ld You should seek for my iniquity And*ld search out my sin,
Although*ld You know that I am not wicked, And*ld there*i is*i no one who can deliver from Your hand?
‘Your*ln hands have made me and fashioned me, An*ld intricate unity; Yet*ld You would destroy me.
Remember,*ld I pray, that You have made me like clay. And*ld will You turn me into dust again?
Did*ld You not pour me out like milk, And*ld curdle me like cheese,
Clothe*ld me with skin and flesh, And*ld knit me together with bones and sinews?
You*ld have granted me life and favor, And*ld Your care has preserved my spirit.
‘And*ln these things*i You have hidden in Your heart; I*ld know that this was*i with You:
If*ld I sin, then You mark me, And*ld will not acquit me of my iniquity.
If*ld I am wicked, woe to me; Even*ld if*i I am righteous, I cannot lift up my head. I*ild am*i full of disgrace; See*ld my misery!
If*ld my*i head*i is exalted, You*ld hunt me like a fierce lion, And*ld again You show Yourself awesome against me.
You*ld renew Your witnesses against me, And*ld increase Your indignation toward me; Changes*ld and war are ever*i with me.
‘Why*ln then have You brought me out of the womb? Oh,*ld that I had perished and no eye had seen me!
I*ld would have been as though I had not been. I*ld would have been carried from the womb to the grave.
Are*ld not my days few? Cease!*ld Leave me alone, that I may take a little comfort,
Before*ld I go to*i the*i place*i from*i which*i I shall not return, To*ld the land of darkness and the shadow of death,
A*ld land as dark as darkness itself,*i As*ld the shadow of death, without any order, Where*ild even the light is*i like darkness.’”
